I.   THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) will complement the loan to Credo Bank JSC 
(Credo) for low-income housing finance of up to $25,000,000 or its lari equivalent. The Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will provide long-term financing to Credo to support affordable long-
term housing finance. Credo will focus on funding home renovation and construction in rural areas 
and the periphery of the capital, targeting low-income clients. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  In March 2017, Credo obtained a commercial banking license from the National Bank of 
Georgia.  Through  its  68  service  centers,  Credo  is  a  leading  financial  service  provider  for 
households as well as micro and small enterprises (MSEs), serving 230,000 MSE borrowers, of 
whom 50% are female, with an average loan size of GEL2,300. The rationale behind the bank’s 
transformation was to scale up lending to MSEs and cater to the growing and more diversified 
client needs, while leveraging its large customer base, of which more than half are female, to 
attract local currency deposits and offer full-scale retail banking products. Credo believes that its 
clients have significant potential to grow their income and livelihood through better understanding 
and management of business and finances, under challenging conditions in the rural economy. 
Since most of the female labor force works in the rural economy, a special focus on women is 
warranted.  
 
3.  Credo’s traditional branch distribution channels need to be augmented by modern fintech 
solutions  to  reach  out  to  customers  efficiently,  especially  in  remote  rural  areas.  Low-cost 
branchless service channels such as internet and mobile banking are essential to facilitate timely 
and convenient service delivery. Credo also needs to broaden its lending service focus by offering 
savings,  insurance, cash  management,  and  payment  services.  A  branchless  approach  will 
particularly benefit females, as Credo moves from a microcredit approach to a full-service bank. 
 
4.  In 2015, Credo established an in-house academy to train its staff. It plans to expand its 
mandate and recalibrate its training curriculum to build the necessary skills for:  
(i)  staffs’ management and leadership skills in the regions; 
(ii)  staff in providing full banking services beyond credit, such as mobile payments, 
transfers, savings, and deposits; 
(iii)  village counselors, who are the main intermediaries to identify clients in rural 
communities; and 
(iv)  building business planning and financial skills of its customers, with an emphasis 
on female clients.  
 
5.  With the support of the TA, Credo aims to achieve the following results by 2022: 
 
a.  Training  
 
(i)  Academy facilities providing an annual training capacity of 2,500 trainees; 
(ii)  At least 2,500 staff and 120 middle managers benefit from full banking services 
and management training annually; 
(iii)  At least 1,300 village counselors, of which 35% are women, have been trained in 
full banking service offerings through the academy;

2 
(iv)  At least 10,000 women benefitting from financial literacy training via “village day” 
(marketing) events; and 
(v)  At least 1,600 female customers per year receive rural tourism business training. 
 
b.  Service outreach and utilization 
 
(i)  A Fintech solution offering full banking services in at least 1,300 Georgian villages 
is fully functional (2020); 
(ii)  Half of Credo’s clients use branchless services and at least 70% of whom are 
satisfied with the service quality; and 
(iii)  The number of rural women using branchless banking services reaches 30,000, of 
whom at least 70% are satisfied with the service quality. 
 
c.  Impact 
 
(i)  Market surveys in 2021 and 2023 will measure the success of the training program 
(with a special focus on female beneficiaries) via improved business sales and 
financial management skills; and 
(ii)  Credo will adjust the training curriculum as necessary based on the market surveys. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
Output 1: Mobile banking solution provides full banking service outreach to rural 
areas.  
 
6.  Under the TA, Credo will establish its internet and mobile banking service channel to 
enable  its  retail  customers  in  rural  areas  to  manage  accounts,  cards,  and  loans;  perform 
payments; and manage personal finance. Its MSE customers will be able to manage cash, 
corporate payments, transaction approvals, salary processing, accounts, and loan management 
through the system. The branchless system will particularly benefit female customers in rural 
areas with difficult access to branches, thereby improving outreach to remote villages and 
reducing transaction costs for clients. Credo’s lending services will also benefit from mobile 
banking applications, and loan officers will use mobile devices and applications to process and 
disburse loans as well as cross-selling other banking services on-site. Disbursements will be 
credited to cards made available to customers providing cash through Credo’s branches and 
Georgia’s automated teller machine infrastructure and point of sale terminals. The introduction of 
a branchless banking solution will require a review and adaptation of the existing business 
processes, which will also form part of this TA.  
 
Output 2: Training Targeted at Women Customers 
 
Output 2.1: Credo Academy.  
 
7.  Credo will train its regional middle managers, relationship and loan officers, and village 
counselors to ensure that full banking services are delivered to Credo’s target clientele. Topics 
will cover (i) sales and marketing, (ii) responsible finance, (iii) relationship management and 
communication, (iv) leadership coaching for managers, and (v) full banking product and service 
offerings. Training will be carried out by internal trainers and consultants with at least 5 years of 
experience in the respective field.

3 
Output 2.2: Financial literacy training via village days.  
 
8.  Credo will augment its marketing-focused village days, which cover 60 events per year in 
rural Georgia, by introducing financial literacy and business skills training modules targeted at 
women. The topics will cover basic accounting and planning, budgeting, and marketing for 
businesswomen.  Training  will  also  provide  information  on  the  benefits  of  service  offerings 
covering credit and deposit and payment services. The training aims to improve rural women’s 
ability to:  
(i)  distinguish between usurious offers and responsible finance practice;  
(ii)  understand their need for credit and debt service capacity; and  
(iii)  improve their business skills beyond subsistence activities.  
 
Output 2.3 Business skills training for women clients in rural tourism.  
 
9.  Credo will also prepare a training curriculum targeted at prospective rural customers 
participating in its housing finance and home renovation program, including the benefits of income 
generation via agritourism. Designed predominantly for women who run small homestays and 
guesthouses, this program will augment basic business management skills via training in basic 
accounting, budgeting, service management, marketing, and the use of sustainable technologies. 
From 2019 to 2021, an expected 3,200 clients in Kazbegi, Svaneti, Adjara, Bakuriani, and Borjomi 
regions will benefit from the program. This training program will be provided in the context of the 
village days marketing context in the targeted regions. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.3 million, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  ADB will delegate the administration of the TA to Credo Bank, which will be the executing 
agency.  Credo’s  management  team  will  manage  the  TA  and  has  adequate  management 
capabilities and processes in place to execute the TA. Credo will report internal audit findings to 
ADB annually.  
 
12.  ADB will disburse the TA funds directly to Credo through an advance payment facility, 
following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). TA implementation is expected to begin in January 2019 and be completed by 31 December 
2023. 
 
13.  The execution of the TA requires the selection of consultants. ADB will monitor the 
selection and procurement steps, check that the use of funds complies with relevant ADB policies, 
and check that outputs for development effectiveness are on track. 
 
14.  Credo and ADB will enter into a TA agreement that sets out the terms and conditions for 
the TA, including Credo’s responsibilities in selecting, contracting, and managing the consultants, 
and auditing procedures, in a manner acceptable to ADB. The TA agreement will (i) refer to the 
selection and contracting frameworks to be used, (ii) confirm ADB’s concurrence at each relevant 
stage of the selection process, and (iii) require documentation of the execution of the TA. 
Procurement (including consulting services) to be financed by ADB TA funds will follow the ADB

4 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB 
Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time).  
 
15.  Credo will provide ADB with annual TA progress reports, including information on the: 
(i)  identification of technical and product solutions; 
(ii) implementation  plans,  including  the  design,  testing,  and  rollout  of  products, 
branchless banking solutions; and financial and business literacy training;  
(iii) TA execution; and  
(iv) TA impact tracking and monitoring of target results.

17.  Consulting services. The procurement will be in accordance with ADB Procurement 
Policy and Regulations (2018 as amended from time to time). Credo will prepare the TOR and 
budget estimates for consultants in accordance with the TA agreement. The expertise and the 
key selection and evaluation criteria will be set out in the TOR or requests for proposal (RFPs) for 
each contract. The services will be carried out by national and international consultants through 
(i) qualified firms, and/or (ii) individuals domiciled in Georgia with at least 5 years of relevant 
experience. RFPs and resulting consulting contracts for firms and individuals will follow standard 
formats  acceptable  to  ADB.  Qualified  firms  and  individuals  are  required  to  have  in-depth 
experience in:  
(i)  retail banking product design with a focus on Georgian non-credit retail products;  
(ii)  financial literacy training and distance learning; 
(iii)  banking product marketing (payments, loans and deposits) in rural areas with a 
special focus on low financial literacy female clients;  
(iv)  performance tracking of client response to marketing campaigns;  
(v)  marketing surveys targeting women across offered banking products;  
(vi)  recalibration of marketing and financial literacy training based on client response;  
(vii)  curricula and staff training in comprehensive banking product offerings with a 
special focus on female customers; and

5 
(viii)  design and integration of FinTech banking services (credit, payments, deposits, 
insurance) in Credo’s core banking system.   
 
18.  Credo will select consulting firms through Quality Based Selection (QBS) and will use 
either time-based contracts or lump sum contracts, depending on the scope of the assignment. 
Individual consultants may also be selected. Credo will not use any ADB TA Funds for payment 
of any applicable taxes and will be solely liable for payment of any such taxes from its own funds.  
 
19.  Audit. Credo’s audit department will oversee Credo’s compliance with the selection and 
contracting of consultants and use of funds in accordance with sound banking practices. Credo 
will also contract an external audit on Credo’s compliance with the TA agreement including the 
use of ADB funds at the end of the TA. Credo will be delegated the execution of the TA component 
funded by ADB in accordance with ADB policies and commercial practice acceptable to ADB.  
 
E.  Governance 
 
20.  ADB has carried out a procurement capacity assessment of Credo, which found Credo’s 
procurement  procedures  to  be  satisfactory.  Integrity  due  diligence  has  been  conducted  in 
accordance with ADB’s Integrity Due Diligence Guidelines for Nonsovereign Operations as part 
of the Private Sector Operations Department’s due diligence for the loan transaction presented in 
the RRP. ADB’s review of the ownership structure does not give ADB cause to believe that such 
entity has been established or is being used for cross-border tax evasion, money laundering, or 
terrorism financing in the jurisdictions involved in the investment.
